In the Drops: Oakley BXTR sunglasses, a nifty tool from SRAM, some Santini fuzz and ‘Welcome to Wrexham’

After a late summer flurry of bike and product launches, things on the tech front seem to have quietened down this week, which has allowed the Cyclist team to publish a wider variety of content.

Tech writer Charlotte Head kicked the week off with a nice opinion piece on the pitfalls of integration, followed that up with an update to our cargo bib shorts buyer’s guide, then kept the ball rolling with a review of Lapierre’s latest Pulsium and an update to our women’s bib shorts buyer’s guide.

In fact, our audience is spoilt for choice in terms of the latest advice, as we updated our pedals guide and overshoes guide too.

Editorial assistant Robyn Davidson delivered another instalment of Pro Log on Monday, and bookended the week with her guide to Il Lombardia.

All that aside, my personal content highlights from this week include an in-depth review of the new Garmin Edge 540, a feature on the unique London Bike Kitchen, and a look at a beautiful bike made by Lord Cycles.

Oakley BXTR Metal sunglasses

The new Oakley BXTR Metals are far more of a heritage piece than their futuristic looks would suggest, as they pay homage to an older design. To multiple classic Oakley designs, in fact. Their most striking feature, the ‘trigger’ shape arms, harks back to the original Razor Blade models from 1987.

However, the use of metal to produce those arms is actually a tip of the cap to a model even further in the past: Oakley’s very first sunglasses, a prototype of the Eyeshades, which were essentially cobbled together from a snow goggle lens and a wire coat hanger.

While they are retro in inspiration, Oakley says the BXTR Metal’s performance is as modern as it gets. Oakley’s ‘Unobtainium’ rubber nose pad and ear socks promise a secure fit even on sweaty skin, while the metal arms are bonded to BiO-Matter plastic frames, in an attempt to provide lightweight durability. BiO-Matter is an updated version of Oakley’s previous O-Matter plastic, which is now partially derived from castor oil.

Being Oakley, the BXTR Metal’s large shield lens is just as techy as its frame, being scratch and impact resistant, and benefitting from the brand’s well-regarded Prizm tint technology. Prizm claims to enhance colour and so the rider can see in more detail. Look good, see well, win-win.

SRAM Ultimate Piston Press

SRAM recently produced a Universal Bleed Block to supersede its myriad other derivations of the tool. It is comprised of a pair of sliding wedges: depending on where the wedges are located relative to one another determines the overall thickness of the bleed block, meaning it can be configured to do the job in a variety of calliper types.

This isn’t that, though. SRAM’s Ultimate Piston Press is the Universal Bleed Block’s juiced-up bigger brother. It can serve as a static bleed block, but its width can also be manually adjusted when installed in the calliper, allowing the user to reliably coax stubborn pistons back into place without risk of them not retracting squarely or being damaged.

It is made of machined aluminium too, versus the UBB’s moulded plastic, definitely positioning it as a piece of workshop bling. Its price reflects that, but its utility for SRAM users and build quality will no doubt make that easier to stomach for plenty of keen mechanics.

Santini Ovis jacket

Santini’s Ovis jacket is part of the brand’s new Terranova line, which the brand says is a range of apparel that is generally casual in appearance but contains technical features that mean it can be used comfortably on the bike too.

The Ovis is Santini’s more technical take on the insulated pile fleece jacket that is popular with the youth these days. The body fabric isn’t just any fleece, it’s Polartec’s thermofleece, and as if that wasn’t insulative enough, Santini has covered the shoulders of the jacket in windproof nylon, so less of your hard-earned body heat gets whisked away by chilly breezes.

Santini cautions that it should be saved for proper winter conditions, and after a sweaty first use in late September, I’m inclined to suggest that recommendation is one to observe. The Ovis’ cut is much looser than typical Santini kit, so consider sizing down by at least one to get a proper fit.

  • Buy now from Santini (£180)

What we’re into this week: Welcome to Wrexham

This documentary is in its second series on Disney+ and chronicles the fortunes of Welsh football club, Wrexham AFC. Wallowing in English football’s fifth tier, the club was bought by Hollywood actors Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney in September 2020 and the investment they’re putting into the club has been a much-needed shot it in the arm for club and the newly-minted city alike.

Courtesy of Reynolds’ and McElhenney’s interview commentary, Welcome to Wrexham charts the club’s highs and lows both on and off the pitch over the last two seasons with flippant pace. It makes for an entertaining watch, but the program is not without heartfelt moments as the indirect impact of the actors’ investment on the wider community of Wrexham is tastefully documented.

The shrewd, calculative machinations that will have informed the actors’ decision to get involved with the club are glossed over to an extent (there’s no doubt that Wrexham was picked for its growth potential in a business sense more than anything else), but generally, given the club itself is now on an upward trajectory and the city is passionately behind it and its new owners, Welcome to Wrexham is a feel-good series that is worth investing your time in.
